docs.snippet: ''We Are The World,'' the all-star recording that raised millions of dollars for African famine relief, and Phil Collins, the veteran British rock star, each won three Grammys tonight.   ''We Are The World,'' an anthem that was written by Lionel R...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''We Are The World,'' the all-star recording that raised millions of dollars for African famine relief, and Phil Collins, the veteran British rock star, each won three Grammys tonight. ''We Are The World,'' an anthem that was written by Lionel Richie and Michael Jackson and recorded by 45 top stars, was voted song of the year and picked up two more Grammys for best pop group performance and best short video. Mr. Collins's album ''No Jacket Required'' was voted best album of the year. Mr. Collins also won the Grammy as best pop male vocalist and shared producer of the year honors with Hugh Radgham. ''I think my mom would have been proud of me tonight,'' Mr. Collins said.

headline.main: 'WE ARE THE WORLD' TAKES 4 GRAMMY AWARDS

docs.snippet: Costa Rica has agreed to work with Nicaragua to establish ''a permanent force of inspection and vigilance'' charged with keeping peace along their border.   In talks on Monday, the two countries agreed to hold another session on March 12 in San Jo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Costa Rica has agreed to work with Nicaragua to establish ''a permanent force of inspection and vigilance'' charged with keeping peace along their border. In talks on Monday, the two countries agreed to hold another session on March 12 in San Jose, the Costa Rican capital, to discuss the makeup and financing of a border patrol force. Relations between Costa Rica and Nicaragua, which neared the breaking point last year, have been improving in recent weeks. The agreement concluded Monday appeared to be the most substantial step yet taken to reduce tensions in the border area.

headline.main: NICARAGUA AND COSTA RICA HOPE FOR PACT

byline.original: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: EARLY on, we hear, ''I can resist everything except temptation.'' Later, ''Wicked women bother one, good women bore one - that's the only difference.'' And near the end, ''A cynic is a man who knows the price of everything and the value of nothing...
docs.lead_paragraph: EARLY on, we hear, ''I can resist everything except temptation.'' Later, ''Wicked women bother one, good women bore one - that's the only difference.'' And near the end, ''A cynic is a man who knows the price of everything and the value of nothing.'' We are very definitely in the sparkling epigrammatic theater world of Oscar Wilde. These particular sallies happen to be from ''Lady Windermere's Fan,'' which can be seen at 9 this evening on cable's Arts and Entertainment network. The intriguing production was produced last year for the BBC by Louis Marks. The director is Tony Smith. ''Lady Windermere's Fan'' was written in 1892, three years before Wilde was arrested on a morals charge that would leave his life in ruins. On the surface, his plays, including ''An Ideal Husband'' and ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' are somewhat brittle displays of wit, as formidable in their cleverness as are the hypocrisies of the society they attack. Wilde, in fact, has hardy roots in Restoration comedy. But beneath the always exquisite manners and settings, beneath the verbal gymnastics of his exercises, there can sometimes be found surprisingly dark recesses. Wilde was, after all, very Irish.

headline.main: 'LADY WINDERMERE'S FAN' ON A&E CABLE CHANNEL

docs.snippet: ''NO,'' Bill Haber was saying, ''I've never been in a cemetery looking for a missing ball- player. But I deal with cemeteries frequently.''   By vocation, Haber of Brooklyn is a baseball historian and statistician. By avocation, he tracks presumab...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''NO,'' Bill Haber was saying, ''I've never been in a cemetery looking for a missing ball- player. But I deal with cemeteries frequently.'' By vocation, Haber of Brooklyn is a baseball historian and statistician. By avocation, he tracks presumably dead, obscure baseball players.

docs.snippet: This week, Dr. T. Berry Brazelton - an associate professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School, founder of the child development unit at the Children's Hospital in Boston and a prolific author - is observing the third birthday of a child of hi...
docs.lead_paragraph: This week, Dr. T. Berry Brazelton - an associate professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School, founder of the child development unit at the Children's Hospital in Boston and a prolific author - is observing the third birthday of a child of his own - ''What Every Baby Knows.'' The program is a half-hour colloquium on infants and their parents that is carried by Lifetime weekdays at 8:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. The series combines candid interviews with parents facing a particular child-care problem and discussions with groups of parents in similar situations. Programs ''try to give parents a chance to see what's going on in their child, so they can make choices based on real solutions and not just on emotions,'' Dr. Brazelton said last week. ''We want to make child behavior explicit - to show what this nonverbal creature is trying to tell us with his actions.''

headline.main: A CHILD CARE EXPERT OFFERS ADVICE ON BRINGING UP BABY

docs.snippet: Though this year's Academy Awards will not be known until March 24, the artistry and craftsmanship that captured a total of 11 of last year's will be displayed on cable for the first time this week, when ''Amadeus'' is shown at 7 on Saturday eveni...
docs.lead_paragraph: Though this year's Academy Awards will not be known until March 24, the artistry and craftsmanship that captured a total of 11 of last year's will be displayed on cable for the first time this week, when ''Amadeus'' is shown at 7 on Saturday evening on WHT, followed by ''The Killing Fields'' at 8 on HBO and Showtime. A combination of expert drama, fine performances and extraordinary spectacle, ''Amadeus,'' Milos Forman's screen translation of the hit Peter Shaffer play about the divine genius of Mozart and the consuming rivalry of Antonio Salieri, was not only named the year's best picture; it won Oscars for Mr. Forman as best director, for F. Murray Abraham as best actor (in the role of Salieri) and for Mr. Shaffer for screenplay adaptation. ''Amadeus'' also won the awards for art direction, costume design, makeup and, not surprisingly - in light of its splendid music from operas, concertos, sonatas and masses - for sound.

docs.snippet: The murder of a Philippine-American news executive that gave rise to accusations of political terrorism has turned out to be the result of a family dispute, the police in suburban Glendale said today.   The teen-age son of Oscar Salvatierra, the s...
docs.lead_paragraph: The murder of a Philippine-American news executive that gave rise to accusations of political terrorism has turned out to be the result of a family dispute, the police in suburban Glendale said today. The teen-age son of Oscar Salvatierra, the slain executive, and the son's girlfriend were arrested Thursday night in the killing, the police said. The slaying Tuesday had been linked by opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines to agents of Mr. Marcos. Mr. Salvatierra, a 41-year-old business executive for The Philippine News of Los Angeles, an anti-Marcos weekly, was shot several times in the head as he lay in bed at his home in Glendale. He received a note the previous day accusing him of ''lies'' against his ''countrymen'' and threatening his life, according to his colleagues.

headline.main: SON HELD IN DEATH OF A MARCOS FOE

byline.original: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The tumultuous aftermath of the election in the Philippines has polarized Philippine-American activists.   In cities from California to the East Coast, there have been boycotts and demonstrations led by opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The tumultuous aftermath of the election in the Philippines has polarized Philippine-American activists. In cities from California to the East Coast, there have been boycotts and demonstrations led by opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who has been declared the winner over his rival, Corazon C. Aquino. The protests are criticized by Marcos loyalists in this country who dismiss the opposition leaders as a radical fringe. Yet, by all accounts, those Philippine-Americans so passionately caught up in an election 6,000 miles from here are only a fraction of the Filipino community in the United States. It is a community said to be dominated by a ''silent majority'' seeking and achieving assimilation into the mainstream. The 1980 census counted 775,000 Filipinos in this country, half of them in California. Of the Californians, 100,000 were living in metropolitan Los Angeles and 100,000 around San Francisco.

headline.main: U.S. FILIPINOS FEEL THE STORM AT HOME

byline.original: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Special to the New York Times
